Wardill ought to see that the wheel bearings are greased, as I never did it, as I couldn't see how to, and she will run hot and melt the bearings if left alone. When she returns, Wardill ought to go over her carefully and grease and oil every hole he finds. I don't know why the lamps should fail except for lack of oil and if Wardill lets you go out without oil you will get fined and he ought to be strafed. I see the Daily Express (Tuesday's issue) has a good deal to say about New Anzac on Sea and implies that it is a swindle. It asks for the names of all people who have got a plot of land there and it might be worth while to send yours up, so that if there is anything wrong you would know about it. Apparently you are to be charged £3.3.0 for Solicitors fees for the Conveyance and one man offered his plot for 3d and couldn't find a buyer. We are now back in camp, having been relieved last night. and go back again to the same trenches in a few days. I am not sorry to get out, but there is nothing to do back here, as everything and place is a sea of mud and we can only go on repairing our fort, which is a dull proceeding. I was up all the night before last as we thought there might be something on for the Kaisers birthday, but it was quite quiet. We had a little bomb show on our own and blew them out of their position in a mine crater which they hold. but these things are of no real value as don't do really much damage with a bomb. We found a position to swipe down the length of one of their trenches, which is an ideal spot and our man loosed off about 50 rounds every time with a target in the shape of a fat Hun, so we must have annoyed them considerable. We have been having some fun with the Division lately as they have been showing themselves rather incompetent lately so the C. O. has just brought them to their knees on one point and I had the A. P. M. on toast while the C. O. was away and our Transport Officer drove the G. O. C. into a ditch last night (unbeknown of course) so I should say that we must be rather popular at the moment. But at times these brass hats are rather trying. The G. O. C. was wandering round our trenches last night, so they took him out over some awful country to look on an isolated post we had got and rather humbled him. I am rather glad he is coming round, as he sees exactly the conditions under which things have to be done. This fairly frightened the staff colonel who was with the G. O. C. The old man was awfully worried when they drove him into the ditch and sent out one of the Brigade staff to control the traffic. as if it was possible to control any traffic with a lot of very unhandy mules in the limbers. A pitch dark night and a road cut to bits with shells and to cram all 2 or 3 feet of mud on either side. I have sent a blue carbon copy of this letter to Odd. Love to all Jack.

My dear Cecily, Very many thanks for a L. O. and Love in a Cottage which I got last night. I am writing this in a cellar in Wipers, where we are for the moment and I am going up to the trenches to-night and back again in ^ a few days time to the same cellar. The whole Battalion I need hardly say is not in the same cellar. but it is in different places about the town and some of it is still back in camp. This particular cellar is dry, but rather chilly and the Primus was very useful last night in warming it up and I am getting it to go again now. I must also thank someone for the London Magazine, which also arrived yesterday. This place is very quiet now though of course they have not given up shelling it altogether. They put a few shells in daily, so I daresay they will be starting soon. I don't know that I have much to tell you. We were not sorry to leave camp yesterday as it is a muddy spot and it was practically impossible to find anything for the men to do, as there is nowhere to do it. However most of them are taken up to the front line at night on working parties. So they want to sleep by day. The weather has changed considerably the last few days and there is now an East Wind which is rather cold. However there is no frost and I think we can consider ourselves jolly lucky in the weather we have had as I don't think we have had frost since November. I am sorry to be talking of the weather, but there is nothing else to talk of except that they have apparently begun their morning hate, as I can hear distant thuds, also the general has just come in and complains that we are very stuffy in here, which must be the effect of the stove though I don't notice the stuffiness myself and would be glad if it was a little stuffy. As it is the cellar is full of ventilators and is in fact rather draughty. Love to all Jack. I have not sent a copy of this letter to Odd as it is such tosh.

My dear Mother, Many thanks for your letter yester received to-day and for the literature about New Anzac on Sea. I hope the place is all they say it is and that it will go well -- if so your plot should be worth something. Please thank Cecily for her letter undated which I got yesterday and for Punch to-day. I am now back in camp and I suppose that we shall not be going up again for some little time. I came back last night and had rather a poor time, as my gee was rather fresh and got startled in the dark by a motor lorry so he reared and hit me over the eye with the back of his head and then slipped and came down I got clear but he was up and away at once quite in the wrong direction. I didn't mind about him so much, but as he had all my kit and Aquascutum, I had to follow on my flat feet. I walked up the road after him for about a mile, but as I was then nearly on the Yser Canal, I came back in a motor lorry. Luckily I had got back about 2 miles and I met my groom with the horse who was looking for me. The gee apparently turned back along a railway and went home and as I heard a train going back, I fancy it must have chased him and given him the fright of his life. Anyway he was covered with mud and had been very hot, so I hope he has learnt a little wisdom. I have not gathered quite what happened to the pram, but I suppose none of you know. I should very much like to know when you find out and what the reason was. After all it may be that it is not strong enough to take 3 people in as I have from time to time. I was rather caught yesterday, as my servant suddenly turned a purple colour and has gone to hospital. I don't quite know why unless he has had too much of Cecily's unbeknownst to me. Anyhow he has gone and forgotten to divulge where he has taken my weeks washing, so there is a clean vest and pair of unmentionables not to speak of numerous socks and hand kerchiefs lying in some cottage round here andI don't know where they are. However I hope that one of the other servants now at Wipers will be able to trace them. I am very glad the Appam has been found, as it shows that they are not sinking them. I take it that G. will wire the ship she comes in and when she leaves. Curiously enough I saw a Zepp. on Monday night. I was going round the trenches and saw a curious light in the sky, which I took to be a comet. I watched it for sometime, but it was very misty and when it disappeared I thought the clouds had hidden it. Love to all from Jack.

My dear Father Very many thanks for your letters of the 5th and 6th and for Cecily's of the 5th. I expect the Lingfield man will find it a bit difficult to get the parts he requires, as I suppose the company is making munitions. I was anxious about the greasing of it, as it is so easy to overlook, but of course if Wardill has done it all right the trouble must have begun some long time ago -- before I had it, as I used to fill it up the grease constantly and probably overdid it if anything. I shouldn't be surprised if Glad turned up in the and the will hardly continue to operate in the same district, as it will be distinctly unhealthy. Many thanks for getting a new number for the pram. I have been on a Court Martial all this morning and have duly sentenced 4 very mild criminals, so I suppose the thumb-screws are now being got ready. Master J. Bourchier has I fancy not allowed his story to lose in the telling. If he is constantly in and near Ypres, he may have been in trouble as they are strafing the roads like anything at the present time. but I thought he was carrying ammunition for a heavy battery and I hardly see how they can be as far up. However I may be wrong. When I said the new binoculars are probably bigger than the others, I meant in magnifying power. In actual size they are a trifle longer, but not quite so broad as my present ones. The aeroplanes are very active to-day, and at the moment they are strafing a up above us and the bits of aeroplane shells are falling back round here. One bit has gone right through a hut and given the occupier thereof a nasty smack on the shoulder whereat he seems rather startled. Since writing the last sentence I hear it is the whole of an unexploded shell which has knocked his shoulder about pretty badly and continued through the floor of the hut 6 feet into the ground. It is freezing again to-night and is rather cold, so I am warming my hut with a wood fire, coal being at the moment unprocurable, though I am shortly expecting one of our mess waiters back with some as he confessed to-day to knowing of a place where it can be obtained, but he artlessly added that he has to wait till it is dark to get it -- so I changed the subject. If this weather continues I must go round and see the N. C. O. who issues the coal with a small gift in my hand. Would you mind ordering a mediumly soft (not floppy and yet not too stiff) service cap for me size 6 7/8 without sunshield. to be sent out at once. I burnt mine accidentally in a candle last night and find the ordinance here have got none. I will send a cheque when I hear what they want. Yrs. Jack.

Dear Father, Since sending up my other letter, I find I have left out the motorman letter and card which I return. I fancy the cost will be covered by my insurance. but there is some question of bearing the first £5 in it I think. Anyhow that question can be gone into later -- especially as it looks as tho' you aren't going to be allowed any petrol to drive it. You will have to use Parrafin and fake up some way of using a little petrol in the carburettor to start her. Love Jack

My dear Mother, Very many thanks for your letter to-day and for Punch and John Bull. You all seem quite determined that I am to get leave soon, but there is no immediate prospect. We are gradually working through the list of officers, but there are 5 or 6 more with the Battalion to go before my turn comes and then there is the question of officers on detached duty. I don't fancy myself that my turn will come before march and I shall wait for Glad if there is any immediate prospect of her returning soon. I am very glad to hear about the pram and hope it is running all right to-day and that Father has had a good run from Oxted. It is now very cold with a North-wind and it has froze the last 2 nights, so it looks as if winter has come. At the moment we are very suspicious of a windmill close by which appears to stop and start at unusual intervals and for no apparent reason. The men say that it stops when troops are going along the road, but that doesn't appear to be the case. However I think they ought to insist that the thing goes all day or stops all day. Love to all Jack copy to Olive sent to-day

My dear Mother, Many thanks for yours of the 10th and for the Caravaners from Cecily. I am none the worse for my fall from the gee, only I am glad to say it was not into soft mud though regret still that it was on to very hard cobbles. I don't fancy there is anything in the naval battle rumor, or we should have heard something here. We had a bit of excitement here last night as the artillery were going for all they were worth up the road and we didn't know what was up, so we were prepared to set out for Berlin at any minute. but nothing happened. I think our guns have been rather too busy lately, so the Hun got irritated and let 'em have it back yester- day in earnest and of course we had to reply. so that is what all the noise was. I don't expect the infantry has had any say in it at all and certainly not in our section -- which seemed so quiet that we thought they had declared peace. I have at last recovered my washing, for which I have been searching the countryside for a week and then only by sending miles away to a hospital to find out from my servant there what he had done with it. I went out yesterday with the C. O. to look at our fort and on the way we picked up the Brigadier and as we were going across country, we made the little man jump a ditch, which was rather too much for him and he very nearly went right in. However we got to the place and found there the Divisional G. O. C. and the C. R. E. (sapper C. O.) and another brass hat and all because we had asked to be supplied with some barbed wire to put round the place. so it shows how little these brass hat shave to do that they should interest themselves in such details. Any competent sergeant could have calculated the amount of wire in 5 minutes, but it took these people one hour to arrive at the amount and I don't suppose they are right now. They say that there was a Zeppelin over here during the excitement yesterday afternoon. I saw some coloured streamers in the air, which I thought had been dropped from an aeroplane but which they now say were dropped from a Zepp. There was a flock of aeroplanes up there too, so I suppose they were chasing the Zepp. Love to all Jack. I have sent Odd a copy of this.

My dear Family, Many thanks for a letter from Odd and an Autocar and John Bull. I took it that Odd will return soon after this letter arrives, so I am not sending a copy. No particular news. The Hun got bumptious yesterday and sent over a couple of aeroplanes who dropped some bombs near a neighboring camp, but no damage. It was rather interesting as the Huns appeared a tremendous height up while lots of ours were flying about below, but of course they couldn't touch him and when they climbed up level the Hun was off though the second one caught it a bit, as we could hear them strafing each other and the Hun descended fairly rapidly to a lower level. The bombs make an extraordinary noise coming down, quite different to a shell but they are ridiculous little things really as they can't take big ones in scouting aeroplanes. The guns were hard at it again to-night and we thought we should have to go up to put things straight and got on the road ready to do so, only they didn't want us at a matter of fact they lose their heads and just because we stir the Hun with activity as we have been doing lately and he replies they imagine he is going to attack when really if he shows a nose above his parapet he gets it strafed off, and an attack is the very last thing he wants to bring off. He did get into a trench up here the other day when I told you there was some excitement on but he didn't stay more than 10 minutes -- as they blew him out with bombs. I went round our R. E. Dump to-day (i. e. their distributing centre) with the C. O. to see the various gadgets they make. They are a sort of Turnery Dept. of the Army and Navy Stores and keep all sorts of odds and ends which are most useful. I shall probably not have time to write to-morow. Love Jack.

My dear family, Here I am again in the burrow and a pretty damp one at that, as we have had a lot of rain the last two days. This particular spot has undergone a lot of alteration at the hands of the Bosch since I was here a month ago. Apparently they spent last Sunday in attending to it and certainly they have succeeded in stirring it up, but no great damage done. The Hun has made 3 attempts on various trenches round the salient this last week and got in to our trenches thrice. Once he was turned out immediately and the other time he wasn't ejected till the next night, and these were partly the identical trenches we first held when we came in last October. They have been tremendously active all round for the last week, but it looks to me as though they were trying to see if they could get in anywhere and now they find they can't it may be they will shut up. Anyhow to-day you wouldn't know there was a war going on it is so quiet. We have had tremendous gales the last few days, to-day without rain, so perhaps things will dry up a bit Love to all Jack.

My dear Father, Many thanks for Sunday's letter which arrived last night, also for one from Cecily and Mother, also for a Bystander. I expect someone has sent me a cap by now, but in the event of my letter having missed you will someone please send me a service cap without a sunshield and moderately stiff. but not floppy. I have a cap badge. My own cap I burnt in a candle the other day and it is now distinctly disheveled. A rather cold and moist day here. not actually raining, but doing its best to do so. It is all very quiet except for the usual artillery strafe which is normal and I think things have gone back to their usual state for the time. Rather curiously there was an aeroplane messing about at 3 a. m. this morning. It was a brilliant moonlight night and I suppose it thought it might pick up some information. It just dropped a few lights and then disappeared and I don't know whose it was our own or the Hun. I am very glad to hear about the pram's injuries that the defects were not very serious. I had imagined that it was much worse and that the bearings and such like things had seized. I am sorry she is contin- uing to give trouble, but that is very likely because the Oxted motor man had put her together badly. I take it that he was to blame because the gear rods went wrong and I know there used to be 8 nuts on the gear box or is it 6 anyhow the full number and he has probably collared them. I am very glad you didn't have to change the wheel yourself when you got a puncture, as it is a hand skinning job and I haven't got the proper tool to do it. One really wants a long tool, a box spanner, to get at the nuts inside and there isn't one. with that, which should be quite easy to get, and the jack there ought to be no difficulty. The latest return which the authorities are now calling for is to the rats in the trenches. This has caused some little joy in our otherwise monotonous existence. Of course the rats are innumerable and of all sorts as described in the Pied Piper and how we are to tell if they increase or diminish is more than I can say. Their name is legion and really I don't mind them so long as I don't tread on them and I expect they do a lot of good as they should be useful as scavengers. The other fauna of the trenches consist chiefly of cats, which I suppose used to belong to the cottages that were about the place, an occasional mouse and all sorts and conditions of birds. We have just had sent us a large .450 elephant gun with which to strafe the Hun. His snipers here fire from behind loopholes and are constantly rather hard to cope with, as when he has fired he shuts up his loophole and defies you. However a .450 bullet doesn't care a hang for loopholes and goes straight through whether closed or open, so we have strafed all the loopholes we can see. and they haven't fired a shot since. Our snipers are pretty useful and we often find that they have a lot of good targets on the first day we are in, but after that they can do nothing as the Bosch doesn't make himself very evident, which is all the better for us but rather dull for the snipers. Of course sniping can now be nothing to what it was, as they can't get behind our lines as they used to, and all the high points houses and trees and such like from which they might fire behind their own lines, are blown to bits. I don't expect that I shall be able to send off a letter to-morrow but will write the next day I hope you get news of Glad. soon Love to all Jack.

My dear Family, I didn't hear from you yesterday, but I suppose the Prodigal Daughter got on the jaw, so you had no opportunity of writing. There is no news here. It snew violently all this morning and is rather chilsome and I am very glad I am not at the moment in the trenches. These guns round here are fairly on the hop and each one makes more noise than the last and they won't stop. I can't imagine why they ever put infantry in this place, as we are surrounded by batteries, and of course the Hun strafes the batteries and when he misses them he gets us, though don't imagine from this that we live in an atmosphere of smoke and shrapnel, because we don't and up to now the Bosch has not actually hit the ground within 200 yards of us and then only twice yesterday when he did some very accurate shooting into an open field about 200 yards away, only unfortunately for him there is nothing there except beetroot. We had some gas shells some little way off yesterday which make one's eyes water abominably. They don't do any harm otherwise. but I imagine that you can't see at all if you get caught by them properly. We have spectacles which are supposed to prevent it, but I doubt if they are much use -- as you are into the gas before you know its there and by the time you've got your goggles on the deed is done. I am going into Poperinghe to-morrow as I want to come to an arrangement with the Expeditionary Force Canteen there as to running our own little coffee shop, which has proved a tremendous boon to the men up here, as we can't get enough up before it is sold out at once. Of course the men get much more for their money as we are not out to make a profit but the brave little Belgians rob them unmercifully. Another difficulty has arisen in that we can't get sugar. Why, I don't know, so I have to compromise on the native sanded grit, which passes for the real article here. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, It is your turn for the news to-day. Many thanks to Olive for a letter from Invergordon and to Cecily for Punch. No mail came in yesterday and I expect there will be others to acknowledge when it arrives. We came into the trenches two nights ago, but only finished this relief about 4 a. m. as we could not start at the usual time on account of other reliefs going on. It has been pretty cold since we have been in and there is plenty of snow on the ground and it looks as if more is coming. However we manage to keep pretty warm, and there is no wind. The Bosch is very quiet at the moment, though he is very busy working in his front line opposite us and we have accordingly been strafing his new work to-day. Some aeroplanes have been over dropping bombs on Ypres, why I don't know as there doesn't seem to be much there to drop bombs on, but they dropped them and the bombs went off, so I hope they are satisfied. I fear there is nothing to tell you, as nothing is happening beyond the usual routine. They seem to be a bit noisy away to the flanks, but here it is absolutely quiet. I can't make out what the Bosch is up to, after all these little attacks he has made. It looks rather as if he was feeling for place to go for, but I don't think he can be very satisfied with the result. Anyhow he has not progressed very far anywhere and his losses must have been pretty heavy. I don't know when we shall be going out again but I think we shall be in a day or two longer than usual as the other Battalions seem to be doing the same. All the recent attacks seem to have upset the ordinary routine and it takes time to settle down again. Love to all. Jack.

My dear Father Many thanks for yours of the 25th received last night and for another box of cigars, on which I will report as requested, but at the moment I am only half way through the last box. so I will keep the others in reserve for the present. I see I drew a cheque for my Comm. Union Premium on the 17th ult and I am pretty sure you have the receipt; I think you said it was in your safe. I am writing this on Monday, but there is to be a show on on the right to-night and consequently there will be no transport up and no post out, and as we are to be relieved to-morrow night, I shall again have no opportunity of sending this off and it will probably not go till Wednesday. The Bosch is evidently making a supreme effort Verdun way -- they say he has 600,000 men there to make the push with. Still everything is normal here, and I should think there would be some signs of life if it was necessary to make a counter attack. I can just hear guns going like beams down in the south, which I suppose are the French -- I think I might hear them as the wind is more or less southerly. The snow has gone, but the ground is in a filthy condition in consequence and it is not yet much warmer. I don't think there need to be any fear of gas up in the end of the salient, as they would be just as likely to gas their own men down the sides as ours and in any case we are quite prepared for gas in any form. A very interesting summary of information from a deserter has come round lately and they say that for a Bosche, he is fairly truthful. He states that our light artillery is much better than theirs, which is rather a surprise. Apparently the Hun bursts his shells fairly frequently among his own men, but such an occurrence is rare with us. he also states that the gunners are very often drunk and that the discipline of his crowd is very lax. They have been punished by having their leave stopped but they refuse to go out on patrol when ordered and generally seem to do very much as they like. He is a Saxon and I daresay they are worse than the others, but I had heard recently of several occasions on which they have had mutinies over the way, so their condition must be very much changed from what it was at the beginning of the war. The strafe to-night is intended to retake our trenches which the Bosch still occupies and I fancy they ought to do it all right. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, Very many thanks for your letter of the 1st and also for one from G. I think I have already acknowledged G's cake, which was very nice and saved several hides as we were starving when we got it. Yours has not arrived yet, though I expect it is in the post and that it I will get it to-morrow. I have had a book from C. and the strand from Odd, for which my gratitude. As I am at the moment in the land of books, please don't trouble to send any for the next few days as there is a book shop next door which supplies everything from the Spectator to the Vie Parisienne -- at a price - and which will probably continue to do so unless the Bosch drops a bomb or shell on it, which he is rather prone to do in this particular place. As you will perhaps gather we have come back for a few days and I came on ahead this morning to take the place over. I imagined that the rest of the Battn. would get back about 10 pm but they are not arriving till 3.30 a.m, so I have got to sit up for them till then. It is a beastly night and pouring with rain, so they will be pretty wet when they do arrive. I am in the town of but I mustn't tell you except that it is the only inhabitable town I ever mention in my letters. The Hun has taken to strafing it lately, so the inhabitants are clearing out and we occupy their beds. My own landlord appears to have a very good spring mattress, which I shall occupy later on. There are a number of shops here and the Expeditionary Force Canteen and a troupe of Pierrots called the Fancies, who I believe are very good, so we are quite civilised and were the Hun not so obnoxious, it would be quite a pleasant spot. The authorities of the place are extraordinarily keen about not showing any lights, as the Zepps are wont to mooch about by night and drop things. so all the windows have to be carefully screened. but this would be necessary anyhow, as all the windows are broken and the rooms are a bit draughty accordingly. Unfortunately our billets are right at the other end of the town to the Town Major's, who runs the place and he obviously lives in the spot which gets the least strafing, so we must pray that we don't get any unwelcome attentions from the Bosch. Tell G. that I will come home as soon as possible. only as I've said before there is no leave going at the moment. Love to all Jack.

My dear Family, Very many thanks for various parcels and papers yesterday. A cake and other things from G. and W. a cake from Mother and John Bull from Cecily. I am still where I was and had an idle day as most of the Battn. was out on a working party last night, so they are allowed to rest by day afterwards. I had a little jaunt this afternoon with the C. O. in a car to see an exhibition of trench mortars firing blank. I think it was chiefly designed to amuse the staff, who were there in large numbers, but we get much better displays in the trenches. There was a new gun there which struck me as being very useful -- in fact it fires so fast that you can get 5 rounds in the air with it at once and another French gun, which is very portable and should be very useful. There has been a good deal of snow again with a North wind and is decidedly chilly in consequence. I had a bath this morning, the first for a long time and feel quite respectable in consequence. I am afraid you have all had to cry off the pram owing to Petrol scarcity, which is a pity, but I suppose there is nothing else to do. Perhaps they will devise some means of letting one get some occasionally - and I see from the Autocar that there is some such scheme at foot.
More snow to-day and I don't think we shall do anything. They say we are back for another eight days. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, Many thanks for yours and Fathers letters which I got yesterday. We have had a beautiful day to-day with a hot sun and I sat out for ½ an hour and basked in it, if you can call it basking when the surrounding country is an arid plain and the only objects in view a number of very smoky ash-heaps. However it is the nearest we can get to basking here. Congratulations to C. on singing at the R. A. M. concert -- I shall look out for the press Notices. To day we went to church in the Divisional Cinema across the road, where a very sloppy young parson came to preach to us. A bad exchange for Frossard who has gone to the base thank goodness. This afternoon I have been there again to look at the Cinema show, which is not at all bad. Many thanks for a John Bull and two cakes which arrived yesterday. The latest rumor is that there is to be no more leave till June or July, so there you are. anyhow it is quite possible, as there was none up here all last summer, so G. had better make her own plans and push off to Erin as soon as she likes. I don't think I shall be able to give any definite idea whether there is likely to be any, till it is definitely announced. Would you ask Father if he would send out the Field Glasses -- I hoped that I should have been home by now to bring them back. The aeroplanes are very busy overhead, but there have been no air fights so far as I could see. Love to all from Jack. P. S. How is the plot of land getting on? P. P. S. The National Review has arrived, but please don't worry to send it, as we get it already.

My dear Mother, Very many thanks for the bundle of woolen things which arrived yesterday and which I am distributing, though I am keeping a pair of socks for myself. They were so beautiful, I couldn't part with them. The parcel included mittens and mufflers, but I doubt if these are wanted any more now -- socks are the permanent need. I hear that we are going out of the salient soon and we have had 6 months of it, so it is only fair that someone else should enjoy its amenities. We have had another beautiful day, part of which I have spent in the Divisional Cinema, which is running regularly now and has the very latest films out weekly, so we are very up to date. That great Drama "On Military Service" was very enthralling and met with great applause. I hope the kitchen is in working order again. I am afraid you have had rather a game in shifting into the Greyhound for meals -- but perhaps the new range will enable all the family to have 2 hot baths a night each instead of only one as heretofore. Intense excitement, as it appears that a working party of ours has gone off in some busses, which were ordered for someone else and their own wagons have turned up and of course there is no one to take and no one knows who the busses were for. So someone is now thanking his stars that his conveyance has not arrived and is marching his men back into camp. Love to all. Jack.

My dear Father, Very many thanks for your letter and the watch which arrived by the same post. A new watch in exchange of the other is distinctly luxurious. not that the other wasn't as good as one could want till it went wrong. I will do exactly as G. wishes about changing them. I am afraid the original one is rather scratched, but so will this one be by the time she gets it and I doubt if there will be a pin to choose between them by the time the other is repaired, and it will save trouble if I stick to this. I am quite sure these are the best watches going, as I notice that everyone else buys those protectors which are advertised, or are constantly breaking the glass. I had no time to write yesterday, as I spent the day in showing various people round the line. We came in two nights ago. To-day I am going to try and fix up a new Headquarters in some old dug outs belonging to the Battalion next door. They cleared out a few days ago, as they thought them unhealthy, the Bosch having dropped a few crumps near by but I am pretty sure that he was aiming at a new support trench of ours, which has been recently built quite near by and which evidently looked too young and innocent to please the Bosch, so he strafed it and pretty successfully too. The last 2 days have been very warm and springlike and life in a dugout is quite pleasant. Yesterday was cloudy but to-day is bright and the aeroplanes are strafing away overhead. One of ours came down behind here just now, I suspect because of engine trouble, as it came down very slowly, but every machine gun in the Hun trenches was turned on to it and the wretched airman must have had a poor time. Two Hun aeroplanes are overhead, looking for him I suppose and when found they will set to work on him with shrapnel and whizz-bangs. I was interested to hear that you had the chance of going for the Conscientious Objectors, as it would have been rather fun The C. O. suggests that they should be formed into wiring parties, to go out in front of the line and make up the barbed wire. They wouldn't want arms, as there would be a covering party in front and nothing could be more in the course of peace than to put obstacles between 2 parties who are supposed to be most anxious to get at each other. Incidentally they would discover something about the beloved Prussian and possibly stop a bullet or two intended for the better men behind. There is no more news about leave and I have no idea when it is to begin again. One can't see any reason for it at the moment and it may be that the C. in C. doesn't think that warfare and leave are compatible and consequently that there won't be any more. Love to all Jack.

My dear Father, Very many thanks for your letter and the glasses, which are A1. Also to mother for her letter and an Autocar. I am sorry her foot is troubling her and hope the pram will help her to get about. Also to G. and W. for food and drink. The latter went down very well on the last night I was in the trenches and I hope in the salient and we buzzed the bottle and to C. and O. for letters. I am very glad C did so well at the concert and I daresay there will be more soon to disport herself at. Leave has really started and we are sending a batch to-day and another at the end of the week and so on at 4 day intervals, so I really do think I may be back soon, but even now I cant say exactly when. I went over in a bus yesterday to our new billeting area near Bailleul and found someone else arranging to billet his people in the same place as mine. However on returning I got him turned out and I suppose he is now scouring the countryside for more billets and I know there aren't any. However it won't do them any harm, as he is a Field Ambulance bloke and they sit on their latter ends and twiddle their thumbs and for the most part might as well be back at home. Though of course they keep a certain number up the line. The new place is in more or less hilly country and is much more attractive than this and the people are French and very nice -- at least they were to me yesterday and I expect they will be to the men. On my way down the other night I stopped in Wipers and had a look round the Cathedral and Cloth Hall, but it is difficult to see anything to bring away, as the floors are covered with the vaultings of the roof. However I got a few bits of green glass out of the doors of the Cloth Hall and a bit of alabaster and bit of painted wood out of the Cathedral, but they are nothing very definite and might just as well have come out of the Station or any ruined place. I have got to go in charge of the Brigade Transport to-day to the new area -- a rotten job, as there is about a mile of it and they all leave the column at different and probably the wrong places and the guides which are to meet them will either not be there or if there be unable to guide -- guides out here always are like that. Yesterday on our journey we passed an aerodome and it was very curious at dusk the way the machines dropped in out of nowhere and absolutely quietly and ambled off to their sheds. Did I tell you that in the Intelligence the other day some machine was reported, I forget whether ours or a Bosch to have been seen to loop the loop six times in succession and for no apparent reason. Pure lightheartedness I suppose. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, Very many thanks for your last letter. I hope your foot is all right now, and if not that the pram is still useful as a conveyance. We are now in France, which sounds as though we have gone a long way but really it is not much more than 4 miles from where we were before. Still we are in hilly country which I thought very pleasant when I first saw it, but am beginning to change my mind as I plough my way round to the billets and have to climb to them by the muddiest lanes imaginable. It is also beginning to snow again, which is not a pleasant change after last weeks warmth and sunshine. We should be here for a few days before moving up and I do not expect we shall be in the trenches for 10 days at least. I had an uneventful journey with the transport yesterday except that the Brigade Machine Gun Company did all it knew to lose its way. I found it originally with its nose pointing up the wrong road and facing the wrong way. they are new to the country and don't appear to be very intelligent. They also managed to kick and lay out a padre who was with the column, why I don't know, but I don't mind much as I know him and he won't be a great loss. I have got a very good feather bed and spring mattress in my billet, so I am quite all right and we have come into a country that was previously inhabited by Canadians who seem to have made themselves very agreeable. Unfortunately they don't sell whiskey here, as they never do in the area where the Canadians are so I had to send to Poperinghe for ours to-day. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, I think I must owe you a letter and hope your foot is all right. We are still in billets on the borders of France and not likely to move for one or two days. I was to have gone up this morning to look at the place we go to next, but though we waited for some time no one has arrived to take us, so I didn't go. This afternoon I have been studying the country round from the top of an exceeding high hill, from which one gets a wonderful view to the North and East. It was very clear and the sun shone from time to time and we saw the Dunes on the sea coast near Nieupoort and Dunkerque and Ostend in the distance. While nearer by Dixmude and Furnes -- while all the country we have been in for so long was nearer still and Wipers itself seemed no distance. One could trace the line a good deal of the way, as it looked like a desert in the middle of the cultivated area. We could also see the shells bursting at different points and they were putting a lot of shrapnel over the place we have just come from and in places one could see the flashes of the Bosch guns. There is another hill much nearer to the Hun lines further up and I hope to get up that sometime to view the landscape over, as one can see everything the Bosch does from it and his artillery is very inactive in consequence because he gets spotted directly he fires and we can put his guns out of action pretty easily. The G. O. C. said he was coming round this morning, but failed to materialize as usual, so we had to try and do without him! Please tell Father that the glasses are marked with half an arrowhead, which means that they are not passed for Government service. However there is no fault to find with them, except that there must be a small flaw in one of the prisms, as one can see a small crack running across the edge of the right eye piece when looking through it. The flaw doesn't seem to affect the vision at all, as the glasses are beautifully clear. We have just got a new cook for the mess, who in private life is a chef. So we are now living in luxury, comparatively speaking, but he hasn't got all the materials he needs or utensils he is accustomed to. However we have a written menu at night's beginning with "Hor. d oeuvres" and ending with Angels on Horseback and he certainly surprises one by his efforts. In comparison the old cook, who has been tactfully (I did it) transferred to the transport, his meals are as those of the Piccadilly to the Black Dog. The new cook was a Sergeant at one time, but as he was no use as such, he was reduced to the ranks and I collared him outside the orderly room and compelled him to come in. I have now succeeded in palming the mess off on our Doctor, so I am now at liberty to strafe him, if things are not as good as they might be, which I could hardly do when I was supposed to be running it myself and I am a rotten bad housekeeper. Love to all Jack.

My dear Odd, It was so good to see your fist again. Thanks so much, dearie, for writing, as you write such a lot that I wonder you have time to do anything else. Also please thank Mother for an Autocar and Cecily for some periodicals and Mrs. Barrow for a pair of socks. A cake arrived to-day also for which I offer my best thanks, but it is of the currant and almond variety and not sponge to which you refer, so I daresay yours are on the way, unless perchance they are the real cause of the sinking of the Sussex in mid-channel, being so solid. However I will wait and see. I have been sitting on the seat of justice to-day, on a Court Martial and dole out varying terms of oakum picking, floggings, and in one case a bath of boiling oil. To-morrow I am going up to look at our new positions and the day after we go in I gather that the district is quite pleased and you can be out and bask in the sun even 30 yards behind the front line and at the back you can do exactly as you like except on the rare days when the Hun gets busy when you retire below and meditate. This is the last page of my writing block, so I cant write any more, which is a better excuse for ceasing to write than you can give, my fair one. I hope D. W., W. P., and if there is no exceptional strafing and the leave boats are running and I don't get torpedoed in the channel, to meet you all on Saturday next -- I trust it will not prove an April fool. anyhow wd. someone mind taking an appointment with G. Hern Esq. during the week following and I want to see Caroline and A Kiss for Cinderella somehow. Will someone get me a ticket or two for these. I will stand the racket and take you all to both if you will come. Love to all Jack.

My dear Family, I have again moved and am now in a farm house about 600 yards behind the line, but as it lies in a secluded hollow and the Bosch is over the next edge or more or less so, it has not been strafed and except that the windows are mostly broken and the roof is not so good as it was, by reason of shrapnel I suppose we are quite comfortable. We marched from our last place this morning and the C. O. and I came on here, but the Company also coming here mayn't arrive till dusk, as they would probably be seen on the way, so on arrival we had to spend some time collecting wood for the fire as there is no coal. While here the Battalion is split up among 3 farms in an area of about a square mile. and they all seem quite comfortable and extraordinarily quiet. However I notice that the Hun had strafed a cottage on the way up, which was quite all right yesterday, so he is not absolutely muzzled. I think it was probably because the last crowd here had a parting go at him just before they went and chucked over everything they could from mere bombs to 9" crumps and he had to do a little in reply. There is no reason to revise my yesterday's estimate of our reunion viz. Saturday prox, so please expect me then and please make sure that the water is hot because I shall need a bath Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, I find I forgot to put back the Field dressing in the pocket of my tunic when it came back from being cleaned. would you mind sending it out to me? It is a small oblong brown package about 4 inches by 3. I also owe 2 /- to the bootmaker in the Square, Idens successor and shall be much obliged if someone will pay it. To-day is fearfully wet and everyone is in their huts in consequence. Our mess is extremely uncomfortable, as it leaks and we have 2 chairs and one form to accommodate the lot. However I have a very good bedroom in a house 200 yards off with an arm chair, so I am lucky. I think I only have the arm chair because the room was previously occupied by a General of sorts and no-one else has discovered the place or the furniture thereof The men are pretty well off, as there is a Y. M. C. A. in the place and also a Canteen run by the Brigade -- but beyond that, it offers no attractions. However we can get back to Bailleul for an occasional outing and I think I shall have to get there this afternoon. Love to all Jack.

My dear Father, I am very sorry to have heard of the accident but am very glad that you and Mother are not hurt. I shall be glad to hear how it happened though I suspect another car coming out of a side turning or something of the sort. Anyhow I hope you will drive again without feeling the effects. Yrs in haste Jack

My dear Mother, I do hope you are not badly shaken after the pram accident. I got full particulars to-day from Father and am very glad it was no worse. You might have had a very nasty smash, but as it is you have got off lightly. I am glad the pram is not badly hurt. Many thanks to C. and G. for their letters. I have had a pretty busy time the last 2 days, as I am acting adjutant for the moment. We are moving up to-night. Things are quite quiet at the moment I fancy but one can't tell for certain from here If only the weather was decent, it would be quite pleasant, but it is beastly cold and inclined to rain. I am sending home a pair of breeks which I never use to be sold or given away or used as you like It is no good carting them about here Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, Very many thanks for your letter enclosing G's received last night. I hope you have recovered from the accident by now. It must have been something of a shock. I fear I have been remiss for 2 days in not writing, but really I have not had a moment, as the first few days of a job like this are rather busy as one hasn't got the hang of things and has to pick up all the threads. However we have carried along so far without any great disaster, though I am every minute expecting to be called up by some irate individual to know why my return of rum jars or some such important article has not been received. We have had 2 very quiet days in the trenches, though they shelled the front line a bit to-day. We are living very comfortably in a cabaret within 500 yards of the front line, but down behind a hill and though the village is strafed to bits this place is at present untouched. Though the roof is a little draughty. The aeroplanes as usual afford amusement and some of ours were out last night dropping coloured lights -- quite picturesque. Cold but bright Love to all Jack

My dear Mother, Many thanks for your and Odd's letters received to-day. also for the seeds, which I will plant and let you know how they do. The gaiters have also come also your cheque. It occurs to me that you might just as well keep a little money for me, as you are always getting things and I think I might be allowed to pay all postage on other parcels as well, as it is obviously pretty heavy. When the cheque which I enclose is exhausted I will send another, so will you please take out of it cost of seeds and other things I owe for and insist that I pay for postage as suggested. I now want some regimental badges. not officers but the yellow cap badges the men wear. We can't get them issued out at the moment, but it is quite easy to get them privately and I should like 2 dozen They cost about 4 d each. Peter Bye has returned, so I shall be returning to my normal position of looker on at once. Everyone was recalled from leave last week. no one could understand why and it now appears to have had something to do with Easter traffic and was really a big mistake. It seems very hard on those who got home and had their leave cut off, harder than on a number of men we sent on leave and who got stopped at Boulogne and sent back, as I imagine they will be sent next time instead, and get their full 8 days. Our attached officer has arrived. He is not a bad fellow and tries to make himself pleasant, but he reminds one irresistibly of my orderly room clerk when he speaks. He only arrived at about 9.30 pm and the C. O. and I were just going round so we took him up at once. It was very curious watching him, as I was in the same position myself 6 months ago and he was very perturbed when we explained to him that it was a very quiet night. It was, as things go. but I can imagine that one would think it a most infernal din if one wasn't more or less used to it. He is very unimaginative and we showed him a place where we have a man at night holding a string, the other end being held by a listening post, 2 men, about 30 yards out in front. he pulled the string and when it was pulled from the other end, he was much impressed and wants to know if we had any men out in front. I believe he thought the string led over to the Bosch lines, so that we could communicate with them. Another book arrived last night from G. for which I am grateful though I have not had the chance to read much this week. Still windy cold and wet. I think the weather was better last January. Love to all Jack. P. T. O. While Wardill is at it, he might make the pram's acetylene lights to go. The Reservoir for carbide is I think in my room if not on the footboard. the pipes on the car are clogged I fancy Jack.

My dear Mother, I have several things to acknowledge. A Tatler Autocar and other papers, gaiters socks and seeds, if I haven't acknowledged them already. We are now out of the trenches and living in farms and houses further back, though still quite close up as our present Headquarters are not more than 400 yards from our last. We are supposed to take care not to show ourselves as though we are hidden from the Hun. he puts a balloon up behind his lines and is supposed to be able to see all round here from it. I doubt if he can see this place anyhow as he has left it severely alone up to now. He was doing some very good shooting at a farm about ½ mile behind us this morning and I saw several shells go right in clouds of red dust from the bricks. The place is quite uninhabited so no one minds how much he strafes it. I went this morning to look at the farm we were in when I came home on leave. The people who succeeded us used to do physical exercises outside in the open in the morning and of course they got spotted and the whole place has been pretty badly knocked about since. Of course it is empty now, but it was a great pity as there are very few of these farms left intact now and if they go on at this rate, we shall have nowhere to go. The natives describe this division as mad, because they strafe the Hun with their guns so much, and of course he strafes us, and incidentally the natives back. I fear the days we are back will be horribly boring, as one can do nothing except wander about in the fields The men all go out at night on working parties which assemblies I do not attend, so they want a rest in the day. We live alongside a very important main road but unfortunately there is no traffic along it these times and there is so much wind that there are not even aeroplanes to amuse. I am glad that the question of repairs to the pram is settled. I wonder if the insurers are coming down on the people in the cart. Love to all Jack.

My dear Father, I am very distressed at your accident. It is an awkward thing to happen and especially now when you are so shorthanded. I have not heard how you did it and I hope that the horse didn't kick you. I hope you will be able to manage a few days holiday so as to give it a chance at the start anyhow. However I'm afraid the weather won't attract you away from home anyhow not if it is like what we are having, as it is too beastly for words at the moment. I have been back near our Transport lines on a gunner F. G. C. M. Their ideas of discipline are very different to ours and they appear to be run in a very haphazard manner. No excitements here. I heard about the Russians in France a long time ago, before I saw you last as a matter of fact and forgot to mention it. One of our Divisional people had been somewhere near where they are and smelt them, so he says. I believe there are more of them in England learning gunning on Salisbury Plain. I was interested to see the result of the Wimbledon Election and that they thought fit to put in that extraordinarily efficient person. I rather expected that K. Jones would have had a closer run for his money. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother Very many thanks for your letter yesterday. It was the first I had heard of Father's accident. At last we have had a change in the weather and it is really jolly. It appears to exhilarate the Bosch as well, as he has been shelling a lot of the farms we live in on the principle I suppose that we should come outside and enjoy the balmy air and if we did not that he would let the balmy air in to us. Anyhow he has been strafing a farm about 300 yards away this afternoon. A lot of crumps came over but he only managed to hit a barn once or twice. When it was over the C. O. Sent up a policeman to see that our fellows didn't go and pillage the place, as the people used to sell eggs and such like there and the police- man has returned to say that the people are still there, so they are evidently used to it. I think we shall emigrate form here to-morrow, as we are too far from most of the Battalion. We shall go to a farm which is further back and hidden from the Bosch, but which suffers from a battery of biggish guns of our own, which make an unearthly did and shake the whole place. Our billet of 3 weeks ago caught fire last night and has been burning merrily to-day, so the Hun is no doubt very pleased with himself. There was no one there however, but he is evidently still watching it as the C. O. and I went to look at it this morning and after we had come away they began on it again. I shan't be sorry to clear out of here, as the roof room has no ceiling except the floor above, as as the upper story is inhabited by the men, the noise below is deafening especially when they do clog dances, when they have to be repressed. The mouth organs are in use all day long. I have just got one of the new steel helmets and look very imposing in it. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, Many thanks for some magazines form various members of the family last night. I hope to hear that Fathers collar bone is getting on all right. Another fine day and the aeroplanes are buzzing about in swarms. I fancy we have got some new aircraft guns here, as we got 2 of the Bosch planes for certain this morning and they say here that 3 were seen to fall and another one yesterday we brought down in their lines. We move into our new billet to-night and I was round there this morning coping with the inhabitants who speak a mixture of bad French Flemish and broken English. When their French stumped me I tried English in reply and they could often understand. I suppose because the Flemish words are so like ours. The Bosches are still busy on the farm up at the end of the field and have put in 2 or 3 hundred shells there this morning. This time the inhabitants have fled, but their wretched beasts are still in the fields round though they take it all very calmly and don't quite understand the noise. We have got our own men out of the barns at this farm and they are now sitting in the yard, so that they can be put into the shelter trench if the Bosches turn on here. Several of them look exactly like Bairnsfather pictures -- most unalterably bored with the whole thing. It is very clear to-day and one can see the observation balloons belonging to the Hun for a long way down the line. You will let me know sometime what the pram costs to repair and what the insurance people are doing about it. If he can I should like Wardill to fit the electric bulbs in the side lamps so that they don't rattle. He might as well do that when he is doing the rest. Love to all Jack.

My dear Father, Many thanks for your letter yesterday, also for Mother's enclosing Cecily's and Odds. I am very glad you are getting on all right and can tap the Blick without undue difficulty. I also hope you are enjoying the weather, which has been simply perfect the last 2 days. We are in the trenches again having come in last night, and I am back in the same red Cabaret, which is inclined to be rather stuffy, as we have to keep the shutters closed all night, so that no lights are visible which to my mind is an unnecessary precaution as we stroll about outside all day and the Hun can't see us, so I don't see how he could at night. We had an eventful night, as 2 prisoners had come over and frightened the authorities as to possible strafes and as the wind as easterly we were on the look out for gas all night. We did get our warning, which eventually proved to be false. Apparently, it was the Hun who started warning his own men a long way down the line. His alarm was overheard by a patrol of ours who was lying under his wire and so it passed up at once for miles. It was very instructive as it showed how good our arrangements of warnings are -- though it kept me standing about all night which I didn't appreciate so I am going to bed shortly. Just as it was getting dawn I saw a very fine aeroplane fight. We just heard and saw a Hun plane going away back over our lines when it was still half dark, and shortly after he had gone a fast one of ours turned up and chased him. They both reappeared shortly afterwards coming back with ours just behind the Hun and firing when he got the chance. It was very like the pictures one sees in the illustrated papers, as ours was not more than 50 yards behind the Bosch and one could see the spurts of flame from his machine gun. We all thought he was bound to get the Hun, when for some unexplained reason our man turned round and went home -- probably because his machine gun jammed and so he was helpless -- still it was very exhilarating while it lasted. There was quite a good account in the Times a few days ago of this part of the line written by the official Correspondent at G. H. Q. Evidently he was looking over it from a very commanding hill just behind our lines from which you can see most of the Salient and the bit of the line we are in. Things are pretty active up in the Salient, I gather, but I haven't heard that anyone expects a big attack up here, as the Bosch can hardly run 2 big shows at once. I fancy the green tabs the Gunner wears mean some office job and both green tabs and the blue tabs with red stripes which one sees in London, all mean non combatant jobs of sorts though I don't know their exact meanings. Very many thanks for the promise of the regimental badges when they are obtainable. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, Very many thanks for your and Cecily's letters which I got last night. We are still basking in simply gorgeous summer weather, and apparently the Hun is enjoying it as well, as on both sides there seems to be nothing doing for the moment. Everything has come out to an extraordinary extent the last few days, which is all to the goods, as it helps to hide the various places we live in behind the line. I hope Father's arm is continuing to progress. I am afraid it is a great handicap to him, if M. E. is away from the office. I shall have the show on my hands to-morrow as the C. O. goes on leave. There is no news of any sort. We are still very much on the alert for gas, as the wind is in the East, and the Bosch tried it on the night before last at Hulluch but with no success. I don't think he is likely to try it on here, but he might on the people a little way off on either side, so we take the necessary precautions These mean incidentally that we don't get all the sleep we might at nights and consequently these Hqrs. do not present a very animated appearance in the mornings. In fact there are 2 of them snoring in unison next door and another at the table here pretending to read a book but really sound asleep. however I notice they all wake up in time for meals. The two Poles who deserted the other day were met on the road back by one of our men, who remarked "Hullo Fritz" and the Pole was most indignant "Me no Fritz" he said. and added later on when he was examined that there were more who wanted to come over but were afraid, so we are stirring them up to-night with our artillery to make it warm for them so that perhaps more will come over. It is quite a science, the way to strafe the Hun. They start with shrapnel and odds and ends over the ground where the Hun is likely to be. This goes on for about ¼ of an hour, by which time the Bosch will have got under cover in his dug outs. Then we put heavy stuff into his dug outs and then more shrapnel to catch him coming out, by which time he usually gets a little irritated. Love to all Jack. Please tell them not to worry about the prams headlights.

My dear Mother, I fancy I have a letter from you to acknowledge, for which many thanks. I am very glad Fathers arm is going the normal course and that it is not paining him. The weather is still absolutely perfect and one basks in the sun, but we sleep a good deal by day as circs. keep us awake at night. Last night was distinctly eventful as we were in for the full blast of a gas attack, aimed mostly at the Battalion next door, but they made a solitary attempt to get into our trench. However we threw a couple of dozen bombs at them and they didn't get in. They got in next door however where they had a much better chance, as the ground was very much cut up between the two lines which are only about 50 yards apart there, but were promptly ejected. I suppose by now the Censor will have blue pencilled the whole letter, but perhaps if he will consider how difficult it is to get anything to write about, he will allow a little license on such an occasion as this. Anyhow I will risk it to go on. It was the first time I had used my helmet in earnest and it is most unpleasant as I had it on for an hour or more and ^ it is very difficult to see through, especially at night. The show was on from about 12.30 am to 3, when it died away and has been quite quiet ever since. We had some sort of a warning as some deserters I have previously mentioned said it was expected several days ago and two more came over yesterday and said it was on last night, but it looked rather fishy as they were the second lot who had said the same thing and might easily have been a plant. My part of the show was very small, as I was more or less tied to a telephone at Hqrs. and in the intervals had to send of parties carrying munitions of various sorts with which to strafe the Bosch. Of course had the C. O. been here I should probably have been up in the front, but as he went on leave yesterday afternoon he missed it and will be very sick too. However I am quite glad to have experienced it, though I can't say I'm anxious to do so again. Considering all things, I think we got off very lightly. They must have got a good deal more than they gave however, as they shelled a good deal but so far as we were concerned very ineffectively, and our guns were putting it into them well. What casualties there were were mostly minor cases of gassing which should be cured in a very few days. They have cured us of rats, which is all to the good as I saw any number of them lying about dead when I went round early this morning. Curiously enough there was a dog in the trenches at the time and a cat and kittens down here all of whom are sitting up and taking nourishment. The gas simply burns up all the vegetation where it is strongest and the whole of No Mans Land where it came over is now absolutely withered. Down here 800 yards back the fields are not burnt but have quite lost their freshness and one might easily have been moved on into the middle of September from the look of the fields. I must now cease. Love to all Jack.

My dear Mother, I am sorry not to have written since the 30th, but I have had a great deal to do. The gas shows entail a lot of reports and interviews and inquiries into our precautions and general dispositions. I had to write endless reports. As yet they know so little about gas that they want to find out everything, so I have laid my soul bare Gas is a fiendish business and our losses are not light but I hope that most of them will return in a day or two when the effects have worn off. Thank goodness this endless East Wind has changed to the West, so we can now rest in peace, as this thing has been hanging over us for some time though I didn't think myself that we should be in more than the fringe of it, whereas we were in the very middle. The Hun has had a relief opposite too which looks as though he has given up any hope of a repetition at the moment. he frightened us considerably on the succeeding night by sending up a lot of smoke, which our neighbours thought was gas but we did not and it wasn't. To-day we have bagged a number of the new regiment of Huns, as they have been showing themselves much to our snipers delight and we got 6. This is a clear indication of the relief, as the last lot never showed a hair above the parapet or a nose through a loophole. We bagged 6 of these Huns at 1600 yards while they were walking across a ridge behind their lines and this is a pretty good shooting. However the Bosch didn't like it and later on smashed one of our telescopic rifles but didn't touch the man behind. We are going out to-night and I shan't be sorry to get back to somewhere where the leaves are green, as the country looks so jaundiced here that it is quite depressing. We have had a heavy thunderstorm this afternoon, which I hope will colour it up a bit by the time we get back. I hear that the natives in the nearest occupied farm about a mile back are clearing out. They don't mind ordinary crumps but gas is a little bit too thick so they are selling their stock and I am meditating the purchase of some fowls only I don't know how to feed the creatures, and one can't transform the transport into a travelling menagerie. It looks like a circus when we move as it is. The Gunners near by have no such qualms and have bought the dog, a calf as a mascot, a cow to provide their milk and numbers of hen to do ditto for the eggs. I shall look out for these when next on trek. It would make you scream with laughter ^ to watch a party of men in gas helmets. They look exactly like so many ducks and they waddle in the same way, as it is very difficult to see out of one, and when you speak to a man you see a whole row of heads turning round and peering up at you, as you can only look straight in front of your face. Each helmet has a tube sticking out from the mouth which looks exactly like a beak -- the men call it a goblin parade when they have to wear them. Love to all. Jack.

My dear Father, Very many thanks for your letter and the cigars -- the latter are A1 and the former delighted me, as it shows that you can now write. The envelope was a great effort, if written by your left hand, but it is so similar to your usual writing that I imagine you can now use your right hand a bit. We returned last night to find a very subdued and quiet Bosch opposite -- very different from the noisy and blatant Hun, who has been there lately. He hardly fires a shot and we got practically up to our Headquarters last night without any visible signs that there is a war on. We had rain yesterday and more to-day -- evidently that is what the country required as it is getting quite green again and the effects of the gas are wearing off. The strafing has done no good to our cabaret where we live, as it shed a number of tiles and now the wind makes it decidedly draughty. I went round the line this morning, very unpleasant owing to the weather which makes the walking very greasy and difficult. The C. O. returned for lunch to-day, and very disappointed that he missed the show last Sunday week. Mother says that she will no doubt hear from L. Cpl. Cheeseman of other little shows we have been in. As a matter of fact we have been in one and you have heard every word about all I've seen, though he will probably have a lot to say which is absolutely untrue. All these fellows lie like troopers when they get home just to increase the family's admiration for them. I have just seen a letter from him to his Mother which is waiting here to be censored, so he evidently is not coming home. He's a pretty fair rotter anyway. Love to all Jack.

My dear Odd, Very many thanks for your letter yesterday. I hope you will find the new nurses amenable and the patients not too fractious. also that you will get a fair amount of holiday which I fear you won't if there is so small a staff. I have now returned to my original nondescript position, the C. O. having returned off leave. However noone could say I didn't get my fair share as it was great luck his being away while the show was on. Not that there was anything to do, except answer the telephone, still there was the sense of importance which is always gratifying. Everyone seems very pleased with the Battalion, though as I matter of fact they were only attacked by a small patrol. still I can't keep thinking and everything points to the fact that the old Bosch thought we were all gassed and only sent his patrols over to make sure prior to moving over in force and when he found his patrols got strafed he did no more. They've been very nervous at nights over the way since and are evidently expecting someone to come over and have a go at them. There is no news. the weather is fine after a lot of rain yesterday and we are beginning to dry up. I am afraid this house won't keep out the rain, if it continues, as a lot of slates came off the other night. I have just seen my canteen off to go round the line. It goes round in two large packing cases and contains everything from eggs to lime juice. The men appreciate it very much as it varies their diet and a fresh egg and roll for breakfast is very gratifying. The gas show however caught us badly last week as we had 10 francs worth of bread rolls wasted, which diminishes our profits considerably. The Bosches are shy opposite and are not showing themselves -- they are also extremely quiet. Love from Jack.

My dear Father, I had a most thrilling account from Cecily of your adventure with the clique Foster and Co. I hope you were really rude to him but I'm afraid you weren't. It would have been a splendid opportunity to pull him to bits especially with the whole room with you to help. I've never heard such infernal lip as his. All quiet here though wet and inclined to be cold. I hope you see the Daily Telegraph now. After a long course of the Times and happened to get on to a copy of the D. T. the other day and found quite by chance that it is not a fact that the Bosch is having everything his own way. It was most inspiring and I continue to read it nightly. One of our subalterns, Fellowes, was wounded yesterday fairly slightly I think. He came with Charlie Cressy and two others from Middlesex and were a very good quartette and now we've only got one of them left. We clear out to-night for a spell and go back for an unutterably boring existence for several days to a place where there is even less doing than here. The guns had a big shoot on a farm opposite us yesterday. I think it was a sort of small fort, but they laid it out in fine style -- not that there was much to lay out, but what there was has never ceased to be. The Bosch set to work on us in retaliation but beyond covering the place with mud and spraining one man's ankle by knocking in the parapet on to him, no damage was done at all. I am writing to Gladys by this post. Love to all Jack. P. S. I wonder if Foster and Lewis did really mix their metaphors in the way Cecily says. It must have been priceless. Do send me any cutting out of the local papers about it.

My dear Glad, Many thanks for both your letters describing Ireland and Dublin. I would have written before only I didn't know where you were. For all I know you were S. Fing with Waalum in the Dublin Post Office and doing a little shooting on your own or on the other hand you might both have been in prison. More unlikely things have happened. I was sorry to hear you thought Father looked ill. The break must have been a great shock to him and he has been carrying on as usual ever since. I hope this P. L. business did him good, as though it is rather rotten to be openly attacked by blighters of the Foster type, it was rather a triumph for Father and the enemy were badly routed. I am very flourishing. They roused us from our normal torpor about a fortnight ago by gassing us, as you may have heard, but it didn't do them any good and they are very piano at the moment and daren't show themselves, as if they do we snipe them instantly. Incidentally I fancy I milder sort of bosch has come in opposite us and all he wants is to be left alone. They are supposed to be Saxons, but we haven't yet secured a specimen to see Anyhow they carry on like Saxons Rather curiously the fellow who commands the Battalion that relieves us is a Nigerian. He used to be in command of the native troops round Naraguta and he mentioned the Cocks names, as though he knew them. He liked the place very much and wants to go back to it. Remember me to Lillie and other Aunts Uncles and Cousins, whom you may see. love from Jack.

My dear Cecily, I think it is your turn for a letter. Many thanks for all your last. I don't know that I have much news except that we have amassed a number of decorations out of the gas show. Peter Bye got the Military Cross, one sergeant the D. C. M. and 5 others the Military Medal -- not bad seeing that nothing much happened. To-day I have done nothing much. I climbed the hill behind us this afternoon to have a look over the Bosch lines, but could see nothing as it was so misty. It was a glorious day so it was very enjoyable up there anyhow. To-night I managed to get a bath, which is always an event. The men had a boxing competition which was quite good sport. A working party from another battalion happened to be burying a cable near by, but the idea of boxing was too much for them, so they came over en masse to look on and even put up one of their own men to compete. However he got knocked over the ropes twice for his pains, but I don't gather that they went back to their work and I must say I don't blame them. The men are made to work far too hard to my thinking, chiefly by people who have never lived in a trench and have absolutely no idea of what they have to do there. Love to all Jack.

My dear Glad, Many thanks for a saffron cake and a letter was it! well no on second thoughts I don't think there was a letter, but the cake was excellent. None the less madam write at once so that your beloved brother may realise that there are others who take an interest in him besides the Bosch. There is no news. We have and are continuing to broil in most beautiful sunshine and it is much too hot to strafe. Both sides feel alike on the subject and are very quiet by day. I noticed in yesterday's paper a telegram which said how active things are and it named the very place we are in as being one of the most strenuous. You might imagine from the telegram (in the D. T. I think) that we were living in a hail of shells and bullets and chucking bombs at each other all day with short intervals for meals, whereas we are actually as quiet as mice. so if this place is lively Lord knows how they don't expire of freedom in other places. We had some excitement last night when a Hun aeroplane descended with a nasty smack into some trees behind his line. Unfortunately we can't see him this morning, but there is no doubt the plane is there and we are dropping a little shrapnel about to make it unpleasant for the Bosches who are removing the pieces. Love to Lillie and W. Jack.

My dear Father, Very many thanks for your letters and for a box of very good cigars, though I have not yet smoked one as I am just finishing the last box. Please thank Cecily for 2 letters and a paper and Mother for an Autocar. I am glad the pram is recovering. I hope Wardill will see the brakes are relined, as they need it. We had another fine day to-day, cooler than yesterday after a thunderstorm last night. It was very quiet to-day though we heard that the guns had blown up some gas cylinders away on the flank, so they turned on some guns on to the line in our part and they managed to start another couple, showing that the Hun still has ideas on the use of gas. Apparently owing to the wind some of the gas blew over to the Bosch lines and I trust they enjoyed it. We thought the Huns had started another device to-night, as while the C. O. and I were up the line we noticed clouds of smoke coming over the parapet. We traced it to a point about 15 yards from our parapet but couldn't see any reason for it, as it was coming out of the Earth apparently. Naturally we suspected poison gasses or something else equally deadly especially as there was no smell. However after dark they went over to look and find that it was all caused by an old smoke bomb which has probably been out there a long time and got started by a shell splinter, so our fears of underground pipes from the Hun lines to our own and other terrifying ideas are nullified. A bevy of Staff lights came round this morning from the Division and exhibited their usual and absolute ignorance of how a trench should be run. However the Divisional G. O. C. has a good word to say about my report on the gas show, which is all to the good, though how the good man ever got through it I don't know, as it was extremely voluminous and probably only one of thirty others sent to him. Love to all Jack.
